author: kilasuit
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a user/administrator that makes use of MU for updating my pwsh installs, I would like this notification banner to be disabled if the reg keys for MU based updates are present.

As a user/administrator that makes use of MU for updating my pwsh installs, I would also like this notification banner text to be configurable by means of additional registry key or other means including in pwsh.config.json/GPO etc

This is following on from this [comment](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/8663#issuecomment-1116459104) originally posted by @TravisEz13 in #8663 & also other issues including #15644 

`@BrandonBoone  Please open another issue about the language/function of the update prompt.`




### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

As above check for MU update reg key, and optionall do not show prompt if it exists & provide an additional reg key/config option so that the text of the banner can be configured if it wanted to be shown by administrators to thier users.

comments.author: VashJuan
comments.body:
It would also be GREAT to allow auto-update as needed, as an option.
 No 2 week delays, an evergreen PowerShell!

comments.author: kilasuit
comments.body: @VashJuan if you install via the Microsoft Store then it should have no delay

comments.author: psr
comments.body: Surely the issue here is that the JSON endpoint which PowerShell checks is being updated prematurely. It doesn't make sense to say that a new release is available until the new release _is_ available, in all of the important places. I don't mind being notified upon opening a new session, provided visiting Windows Update does have a new release.

comments.author: psr
comments.body: Part of the problem is that showing the message before Windows Update is ready encourages re-installing with the new MSI - giving a new opportunity to opt-in/out of Windows Update. "Didn't I click the option to use Windows Update last time around? I guess I must not have done..." 🤔

comments.author: VashJuan
comments.body:
My (limited) understanding is that there are two destinations for PowerShell updates: 1) MS Store (which I've always avoided like the plague) which gets updated quickly. Then there is also 2) the bundled/verified/slower-updating Windows Update.

The PowerShell extension in VS Code doesn't actually check to see which version is installed, but just whether the PowerShell team has released an updated version - whether it is available or not.

I'm not clear how to switch from option 2) to option 1). I uninstalled PowerShell from Windows Settings/Programs & Features & then went to the Windows Store and installed the PowerShell Preview. But then there are a lot of detailed settings for VS Code/the extension that overwhelmed me: which of the 20 subtly different settings is the right one? tl;dr

Now I'm getting a notice that there is a new pscore6 available: apparently the store install didn't install that???

comments.author: VashJuan
comments.body: @psr, Yep, a lot of fiddling/bother for what 'should' be a boring part of the tooling.
